message: I've been pondering ideas for raising funds for RTD, up to this point it has all been funded out of my pocket.
Thinking something like $50/year ($4/mo) to have private docs for your company, whether thats internal development documentation, customer-facing custom-themed documentation, or whatever else
We've now gotten a couple sponsors on board that have agreed to pay for server hosting
so running the site is effectively free
This would help support the hosting and development, and allow us to become good community members by sponsoring new theme development, and other things to help projects along

I'm curious what people think of the idea of building Private documentation (eg. password protected/user controlled), and then offering that to businesses/institutions as a way to support the site and development going forward
Or anything proprietary  related to my company
for personal 'products' that I'm developing, though, I'd use it.
@ericholscher but if it's *me* building my own proprietary stuff, it'd be awesome, and I'd use it
I love the option, but could never do so with my corporate projects.
it would be quite useful in fact

I think the issue is that if you are technical enough to be documenting with sphinx, you are probably capable of copying sphinx's html output to a in-house http server.  Not as nice as a post commit hook on RTD - but good enough for a lot of in house use
@kennethreitz Why couldn't you use it for something related to your company?
Presumably anything you're paying for would be stripped of all the branding and CNAME'd, so there would be no obvious way to see that we were hosting it
@ericholscher I wouldn't be allowed to use it for any corporate projects. They'd never allow documentation for a proprietary codbase on a 3rd party
Only one way to see for real, I guess
@ericholscher I think it's defniitely the type of expense people would be irrational about (i.e. not realize that the $50 is an hour of their time)
gotcha
@ptone Right. But $50/yr is like an hour of developer time, which you would almost certainly spend more time setting up your own hacked together instance
less than an hour even :)
I'd also probably pay 50/yr for your build/testing server :)
Yeah, I think that 50/yr is totally reasonable, and I'd be happy to pay that.
I'll absolutely use it in situations where it's allowed
@ericholscher I could not agree more but … would you want to have to get on the GSA schedule for our $50/year? ;)
I dont even know what a GSA schedule is...
Oh. Government scariness.
Yes. We were *QUITE* happy to see AWS get onto GSA last fall.
All of aws?
@acdha woah, I had no idea that happened
great move on their part
@acdha We had the same reaction when AWS passed its PCI cert :-)

@ericholscher - I think you'd have to specify more... and I think you could underscore value by making some ridiculously low entry point (just to open the conversation), e.g.:  $1/month:  private access (like private groups on convore - no encryption, just access control);  $4/month:  add encrypted filesystem for your data (spec out how);  $5/month:  all of above, w/ your domain.... anyway, you get the gist of what I'm trying to say.
